questions.question: This river is often dry. So… why does it still matter?
questions.hint: Think: groundwater, floods, habitats, and where towns like to build things.
questions.answer: Even when it looks dry, the river corridor shapes flooding, recharges groundwater, supports habitats, and influences where roads and cities can safely exist.

questions.question: Why is it dry so much of the year?
questions.hint: Seasonal rain + sandy/gravelly channels are a big clue.
questions.answer: In Mediterranean climates, most rain falls in winter, and the riverbed can be highly permeable—water often soaks into sediments or flows underground outside of storm periods.

questions.question: What’s the big engineering problem rivers create for cities?
questions.hint: It starts with “F” and ends with “looding.”
questions.answer: Flooding risk—rivers can go from calm to dangerous quickly, so bridges, levees, culverts, and setbacks are designed around rare-but-big storm events.
